text: 'Emma is Austen''s only novel named after its heroine -- perhaps an indication of how determinative Emma''s strong will and personality are of the story.  Austen most often titled her novels after the abstract traits they explored: Pride and Prejudice, Sense and Sensibility, Persuasion.'

text: 'Why not simply "united"?  Austen sets up her story: the truth beneath appearances.'

text: 'The well-intentioned but ultimately unwise father -- here signaled by "indulgent" -- is an Austen mainstay, as is the motherless young woman.  As they probe women on the cusp of marriage, Austen''s novels often portray family life as somehow inadequate, whether because of absent care-givers or differing personalities.'
quote: 'affectionate,\r\nindulgent father;

text: 'The replacement for the mother often proves inadequate in Austen as well -- compare Lady Russell, a giver of bad advice, in Persuasion.'

text: 'Austen is often interested in the "second chance": many of her female characters overcome wrong "First Impressions" (the original title for Pride and Prejudice), especially Anne Elliot of Persuasion, who gets a second chance at love with Captain Wentworth after being dissuaded from accepting his proposal seven years earlier.'

Ask yourself what "voice" is making this analysis here: it isn''t Emma''s, but would we call it "Austen''s," exactly?  Try to separate out the many levels and types of perspective Austen is able to achieve in what only seems like simple third-person narration.

text: 'Note how the regard of family and of community overlap here, and consider what "eyes" are on Emma as she makes her way through the story.  Note too how the community''s regard for Frank is based on nothing but reputation!  How does a character''s "story" follow him or her around?'

text:
'

The eccentric father is a staple in Austen''s work.  It has been said of Shakespeare''s comedies, for instance, that their plots proceed from a stern father laying down a law (psychoanalytical critics would say "the Law of the Father," after Freud) that forces the potential lovers into the forest (Arden, say) to work out, through magic and trial and error, their true connections.  What effect does a lax father at the center of this novel have on its plotting, by contrast?

'
quote: 'unfit for any acquaintance\r\nbut such as would visit him on his own terms.

text:
'

Having set out her principal players -- Emma, Mr. Knightley, and (for later) Frank Churchill -- in the first two chapters, Austen now begins to build up a social world of more minor characters (and social pressures) into which they will fit.

'

girls might be sent to be out of the way, and scramble themselves into
a little education, without any danger of coming back prodigies.

body else; but you need not be afraid, they are very small, you
see--one of our small eggs will not hurt you. Miss Bates, let Emma help
you to a little bit of tart--a very little bit. Ours are
all apple-tarts. You need not be afraid of unwholesome preserves here.

text: 'Austen''s female characters are often quite adept at assessing another''s financial status -- and it should be noted that this isn''t necessarily always a sign of superficiality.  Austen almost always rewards her heroines in the end not just with a genuine lover but a man of property and wealth as well.'

text: 'Here Austen varies her repertoire of characterization: suddenly we hear what seems like unspoken dialogue in Emma''s mind.  At the time, this sort of writing represented quite an advance in the ability of the novel to depict consciousness.  Moments such as these account for Austen''s great reputation as the creator of free indirect discourse, or, in other words, close-to-the-character''s-mind third person.'

text: 'As is often the case in Austen, a discussion of a particular relationship turns into a "battle of the sexes" conversation -- the real bounty is some hammering-out of the respective natures of men and women.'
quote: 'I am very much\r\nmistaken if your sex in general would not think such beauty, and such\r\ntemper, the highest claims a woman could possess."

text: 'Knightley summarizes his concern in a single phrase.'
quote: 'true gentility\r\nthan

text: 'Austen gives the Emma/Knightley antagonism considerable nuance here.  "Judgment" is always a key achievement in Austen.'
quote: 'but yet she had a sort of habitual respect for his judgment\r\nin general, which made her dislike having it so loudly against her;

text: 'Knightley offers a competing reading of Elton as well.  Watch it play out.'
quote: 'He knows the value of a good income as well as\r\nany body.

text: 'How do you assess Emma''s skills of observation?  How does Austen allow you the reader to observe things through her perspective yet see something other than what she sees?  Many critics have seen this as a novel very much concerned with the parallels between "reading" in the social sense -- judging others'' actions and desires -- and reading in the more literal sense.'
quote: 'the skill of\r\nsuch an observer on such a question as herself,

text: 'Why do you think Austen uses words like "justified" and "judgment," with their legal ring, to discuss Emma''s actions in relation to Harriet and others?'
quote: 'more\r\njustified

text: 'Perhaps Austen is drawing on her own experience of being schooled at home by her father, a rector.  (She also attended a boarding school for three years.)'
quote: 'study;

text: 'Books of riddles...'
quote: 'In this age of literature, such collections on a very grand scale\r\nare not uncommon.

text: 'Walking is a hugely important activity in Austen.  So many meanings of the feminine and the feminist are worked out by Austen through scenes of walking (and falling while walking): mobility in literal and metaphorical senses, the ability to propel oneself on one''s own power, senses lively enough to take in changing scenery.'
quote: 'regular exercise;

text: 'Goldsmith''s The Vicar of Wakefield was one of Austen''s favorite novels, and a model for her own fiction.'
quote: 'Vicarage,

text: 'We again see Emma misreading some basic signs being given off by Mr. Elton.'
quote: 'a proof of\r\nlove,

text: 'Another benefit of walks: they free the mind and tongue from the social confines and expectations of the drawing room.'
quote: '"Dear me!--it is so odd to hear a woman talk so!"--

text: 'In rendering this speech, Austen may have in mind the forest soliloquies of a Shakespeare comedy like As You Like It or A Midsummer Night''s Dream -- where departure from social rules, not to mention the "fool"-like behavior mentioned here, plays a pivotal role.'
quote: 'And, without love, I am sure I should be a fool to change such a\r\nsituation as mine.

text: 'See if, as Austen''s plot plays out, you don''t come to hear Austen herself speaking here.  It has been noted by scholars that, as much as she critiques obsessions with social class, she never leaves her married heroines penniless or even poor.'
quote: 'is\r\npoverty

text: 'Note how, in support of the Shakespeare thesis above, we''ve descended into total dialogue, as though we were reading a play.  The theater played an important role in Austen''s developing formulation of what a novel was and could be.'
quote: '"If I know myself, Harriet, mine is an active, busy mind,

text: 'Emma''s enviousness re-emerges.'
quote: 'wish Jane Fairfax very well; but she tires me to death."

text: 'Do we believe Emma has been deeply affected by the visit?  Why do you think Austen chose not to render its particulars -- is it an ironic comment on just how seriously Emma takes this work?  Ability to be graceful with the poor is a key test of character in Austen, and we emerge from this scene not sure of whether Emma has passed it.'
quote:
'"These are the sights, Harriet, to do one good. How trifling they
make every thing else appear!--I feel now as if I could think of
nothing but these poor creatures all the rest of the day; and yet, who
can say how soon it may all vanish from my mind?"

text: 'Is it being suggested to us that Emma herself is still something of a child, lagging behind in maturity?'
quote:
'To walk by the side of this child, and talk
to and question her, was the most natural thing in the world, or would
have been the most natural, had she been acting just then without
design;

text: 'Love is a journey -- though this has the ring of armies in battle to it, too.'
quote: 'they\r\nmust advance somehow or other whether they would or no.

text: 'Austen chooses new characters to bring in who will allow her, through their relations, to show us Emma and Mr. Knightley in a different light and in greater detail.'
quote: 'Mr. and Mrs. John Knightley,

text: 'Austen creates worlds where fathers are often suspect, if ultimately benign -- where characters often need to seek out surrogate parents unconsciously (often because, as noted earlier, they have, like Emma, lost their mother).  What kind of fathering do we see here?'
quote: 'the\r\nchildren were never allowed to be long a disturbance to him, either in\r\nthemselves or in any restless attendance on them.

text: 'This leads naturally to the question of what we think the other daughter, Emma, has inherited from her father.'
quote:
'she inherited
also much of his constitution; was delicate in her own health,
over-careful of that of her children, had many fears and many nerves,
and was as fond of her own Mr. Wingfield in town as her father could be
of Mr. Perry. They were alike too, in a general benevolence of temper,
and a strong habit of regard for every old acquaintance.

text: 'Austen builds up the case for or against a connection for her central figures by giving us a catalog of marriage types from more minor characters.  Keep these descriptions in mind as we learn of more relationships later in the text.'
quote: 'perfection;\r\nand, indeed, with such a worshipping wife, it was hardly possible that\r\nany natural defects in it should not be increased.

text: 'Is Emma growing here towards some greater insight, in having to express her feelings over the departure of Miss Taylor?'
quote:
'Every body
must be aware that Miss Taylor must be missed, but every body ought
also to be assured that Mr. and Mrs. Weston do really prevent our
missing her by any means to the extent we ourselves anticipated--which
is the exact truth."

text: 'Austen, in addition to highly personal scenes of love, also devotes plenty of public debate to the more abstract issue of marriage and its benefits.  Do you see parallels or dissonances between what''s said here in the drawing room and what Emma said on her walk in the last chapter?'
quote: 'advocate for matrimony

text: 'We hear more of the mysterious Frank Churchill -- but still only in the form of his letters.  Austen is building suspense around this character and also saying something about ciphering -- interpreting -- an individual through words, as though he were a riddle.'
quote: '`F. C. Weston Churchill.''--

text: 'An important theme -- about interpretation of words and persons, and the necessity of it for both -- begins to take shape around these riddles.  See if other characters or instances in the novel put you in mind of the form or impact of a riddle.'
quote: 'riddles

text: 'In this "answer" or final outcome to a text, is Austen toying with our sense of where her novel''s plot might end up?  A riddle is a plot in miniature, and Austen spoke of her writing in miniature, painting delicately on small bits of ivory.'
quote: '"Kitty, a fair but frozen maid."

text: 'In case you can''t figure it out -- "woe"-"man," or, of course, woman.  This is quite a come-on from Elton, but -- as riddles allow her to do -- Austen follows out her theme of misreading rather than letting the right answers be obvious, either in love or in riddle-making'
quote: 'My first doth affliction denote,  /  Which my second is destin''d to feel  /  And my whole is the best antidote  /  That affliction to soften and heal.--  /

text: 'Keep an eye out for letters and private communications in the novel.'
quote: 'have no right to expose it in any degree to the public eye,\r\nbut

text: 'Austen both brings out Emma''s sharpness (but her lack of real insight into others'' intentions) and flatters the reader who can get it before Harriet does.  Again, think of the whole plot of the novel being summarized by this small act of "reading."'
quote: 'Courtship

text: 'Austen''s texts are full of tests for their heroines, and -- if we had any doubt about Harriet before -- she is failing this test.  She cannot hold center stage in the book in the way Emma can; she is simply an insufficient interpretive mind.'
quote: '"What can it be, Miss Woodhouse?--what can it be? I have not an\r\nidea--I

text: 'Is there something here about the way novels, even though they may be about persons remote from our own circumstances, speak to us personally?  What kind of illusion is that, and how do writers pull it off?'
quote: 'being written for you and to you."

text: 'A married woman would, of course, change her name to her husbands (see Taylor to Weston, etc.).  And a proto-feminist like Austen might also note that she starts life with her father''s name.  Are all young women, then, in a way, Miss Blanks, waiting to have their identity filled in by attachment to a (new) man?  Is there power, perhaps, in being a Miss Blank, not yet taken?'
'The meta-fictional meanings of the riddles are reinforced.'
quote: 'It is a sort of prologue to the\r\nplay, a motto to the chapter;

text: 'A line from Shakespeare''s A Midsummer Night''s Dream.  See later notes on the importance of that play''s forest setting to Emma.'
quote: 'The course of true love never did run smooth--  /

text: 'Is Harriet improving as a reader or not?  The ability to recognize a good writer was as important -- and at times concident with -- the ability to recognize a lover in Austen.'
quote:
'"It is one thing," said she, presently--her cheeks in a glow--"to
have very good sense in a common way, like every body else, and if
there is any thing to say, to sit down and write a letter, and say just
what you must, in a short way; and another, to write verses and
charades like this." Emma could not have desired a more spirited rejection of Mr. Martin''s prose.

text: 'There is an interesting suggestion here about the privacy of writing.  Harriet is writing in a kind of public book, parallel to the books of the names and titles of high society Austen satirizes in, for example, Persuasion.  As a woman looking for time and solitude in which to write, Austen as a woman of the early 19th c. might have felt the association of writing with privacy in a deep and tormenting way.'
quote: '--"The best of all. Granted;--for private enjoyment; and for private\r\nenjoyment keep them.

text: 'Questions of inheritance abound in this text, and here we have the suggestion that the quick-witted Emma takes after her mother.'
quote: 'Your dear mother\r\nwas so clever at all those things!

text: 'We are called back to a joke foreshadowed at the beginning of the chapter.  Emma''s father often enters scenes in this way, as comic relief.'
quote: 'Kitty, a fair but frozen maid,  /  Kindled a flame I yet deplore,  /  The hood-wink''d boy I called to aid,  /  Though of his near approach afraid,  /  So fatal to my suit before.  /

text: 'Another marriage is glimpsed -- and a possible path for Emma to follow out of her father''s house?'
quote:
'"It is unfortunate that they cannot stay longer--but it seems a case
of necessity. Mr. John Knightley must be in town again on the 28th, and
we ought to be thankful, papa, that we are to have the whole of the
time they can give to the country, that two or three days are not to be
taken out for the Abbey. Mr. Knightley promises to give up his claim
this Christmas--though you know it is longer since they were with him,
than with us."

text: 'In these names, as elsewhere in this scene that ends the chapter, it''s suggested that all of life circulates between fathers and husbands -- women must be with one or the other at all times, they sometimes have to choose a primary allegiance to one, all the sons get named after one or the other.  When people speak of "patriarchy" and of Austen''s society as a "patriarchal" one, this is the sort of thing they mean.'
quote: '"Henry is a fine boy, but John is very like his mama. Henry is the\r\neldest, he was named after me, not after his father. John, the second,\r\nis named after his father.

text: 'Note how Austen puts the growth of Emma''s mature emotions in such restrained terms.  If we notice a strong distinction between the distanced and authoritative tone of some of the prose and the childishness and indulgence of some of Emma''s speeches, it''s as though Emma''s language has to grow into -- reach the maturity of -- her surrounding text.'
quote: 'She thought it was time to make up.

text: 'But then, childishness (he said, she said) takes over anew.'
quote: 'Making-up indeed would not do. She certainly had not been in the wrong, and he would never own that he had.

text: 'See earlier notes suggesting that characters can be tracked for their fathering abilities and their inclination to be a good parent.  Emma and Knightley are testing out certain things that would be important to a relationship between them, were it to happen, here under the guise of a detached discourse.'
quote:
'"If you were as much guided by nature in your estimate of men and
women, and as little under the power of fancy and whim in your dealings
with them, as you are where these children are concerned, we might
always think alike."

text: 'And so, in a way, old enough to be her father.'
quote: 'I was sixteen years old when you were born."

text: 'Once again, Emma is connected to children.  Austen was quite conversant in the Romantic notion that, to paraphrase Wordsworth, the child is father to the man and the Romantics'' general idealization of childhood.  Austen, in her realistic world, seems to offer a more sobering assessment of the childlike capacity within adults; rarely does she romanticize that trait.'
quote: 'Little Emma, grow up a better\r\nwoman than your aunt.

text: 'The Knightleys (George, named after the patron saint of England, in particular) are repeatedly associated with typical Englishness, here said to be epitomized by a lack of direct affection.'
quote: 'the true English style,

text: 'The many sides to the identity of Mr. Knightley -- at home in the outdoors and in the professional world -- emerge here.'
quote: 'as a farmer,

text: 'Austen writes often of the nineteenth-century medical practice of recommending seaside vacations to cleanse the sick.  See the visit to Lyme in Persuasion in particular.'
quote: '"Mr. Wingfield most strenuously recommended it,

text: 'Austen lived outside of London for all of her life, and here she may through Mr. Woodhouse be expressing a general preference for the slowness and pastoral climes of the countryside.'
quote:
'"Ah! my poor dear child, the truth is, that in London it is always a
sickly season. Nobody is healthy in London, nobody can be. It is a
dreadful thing to have you forced to live there! so far off!-- and the
air so bad!"

text: 'What sort of marital connection is glimpsed here?'
quote: '"My dear Isabella,"--exclaimed he hastily--"pray do not concern\r\nyourself about my looks. Be satisfied with doctoring and coddling\r\nyourself and the children, and let me look as I chuse."

text: 'The implicit contrast may be to Emma and Isabella, whom we hardly see speak to one another.  Why is it that brothers have such strong bonds in this novel but sisters have, seemingly, little connection?'
quote: 'the real attachment

text: 'Note how, as with Frank Churchill before, ''new'' and minor characters often enter a chapter at the end, after the relationships of the more central characters have been thoroughly explored.'
quote: 'Jane Fairfax!"

text: '"Matching" Emma in many senses of the word is a preoccupation, whether it be with men or women.  The Victorian novelist was strongly concerned with social binding -- what stuck individuals together and thus (in novelists of broader social scope than Austen) what made larger communities work.'
quote: '"I am most happy to hear it--but only Jane Fairfax one knows to be so very accomplished and superior!--and exactly Emma''s age."

text: 'So, indeed, who''s acting like a child -- self-centered, narcissistic -- in this scenario?'
quote: '"But why should you be sorry, sir?--I assure you, it did the children a great deal of good."

text: 'The control over the direction of a path would seem to be a significant metaphor in Austen, who writes so much of love and relationships as journeys on foot, by carriage, and by other means.'
quote:
'John, as to what I was
telling you of my idea of moving the path to Langham, of turning it
more to the right that it may not cut through the home meadows, I
cannot conceive any difficulty. I should not attempt it, if it were to
be the means of inconvenience to the Highbury people, but if you call
to mind exactly the present line of the path.

text: 'Notice how Austen moves her potentiall static plot forward through the use of visits and dinners.  The visit -- one set of characters encountering another, often with food involved -- is a staple structure of the novel of manners.'
quote: 'one complete dinner engagement, and out of the house too,\r\nthere was no avoiding, though at Christmas.

text:
'

The "law of the father" still reigns, if in an absurd and easily satirized way.

'
quote: 'Mr. Woodhouse''s habits and inclination being\r\nconsulted in every thing.

text: 'Harriet is gotten out of the way, and now Austen is cleared to focus her gaze on Emma in this dinner situation.'
quote: 'Harriet herself was too ill and low to resist the authority which\r\nexcluded her from this delightful engagement, though she could not\r\nspeak of her loss without many tears.

text: 'You might try visualizing this scene by asking what you would advise an actor playing the role of Elton to do in this moment, were this a stage version of the novel.'
quote:
'Mr. Elton looked as if he did not very well know what answer to
make; which was exactly the case; for though very much gratified by the
kind care of such a fair lady, and not liking to resist any advice of
her''s, he had not really the least inclination to give up the visit;--
but

text: 'Notice how the love connection between Emma and Elton (love connection at least in his mind) is brought about by the offer of a seat in a carriage.  Perhaps this reinforces Austen''s metaphorization of love and life as journeys, but recognize too that, for the early nineteenth-century person of propriety, the proximity afforded by a carriage ride (and, at times, possibly the solitude of it) was something not obtainable anywhere else in the culture.  Key scenes of emotional transport (or havoc) often occur in carriages in Austen.'
quote:
'But hardly had she so spoken, when she found her brother was civilly
offering a seat in his carriage, if the weather were Mr. Elton''s only
objection, and Mr. Elton actually accepting the offer with much prompt
satisfaction. It was a done thing; Mr. Elton was to go, and never had
his broad handsome face expressed more pleasure than at this moment;
never had his smile been stronger, nor his eyes more exulting than when
he next looked at her.

text: 'An outside, neutral observer asserts himself, perhaps knitting together what a reader has suspected with this assessment.'
quote: '"Yes," said Mr. John Knightley presently, with some slyness, "he seems to have a great deal of good-will towards you."

text: 'As Shakespeare said in Hamlet, "Methinks the lady doth protest too much."'
quote:
'she walked on, amusing
herself in the consideration of the blunders which often arise from a
partial knowledge of circumstances, of the mistakes which people of
high pretensions to judgment are for ever falling into; and not very
well pleased with her brother for imagining her blind and ignorant,

text: 'Notice how much emphasis there is, in this chapter in particular, on men''s pleasure and displeasure.  Are women, by comparison, squelched, suppressed?  Why do men''s wants set the tone?'
quote:
'Emma soon saw that her companion was not in the happiest humour. The
preparing and the going abroad in such weather, with the sacrifice of
his children after dinner, were evils, were disagreeables at least,
which Mr. John Knightley did not by any means like; he anticipated
nothing in the visit that could be at all worth the purchase; and the
whole of their drive to the vicarage was spent by him in expressing his
discontent.

text: 'The novel has in many ways become a referendum on marriage and a training ground for it; and here Emma is learning something about the intricacies of married life.  Compare the thoughts she shared on her walk to Elton''s house (are carriage thoughts different from walk thoughts?) a few chapters earlier.'
quote:
'Emma did not find herself equal to give the pleased assent, which no
doubt he was in the habit of receiving, to emulate the "Very true, my
love," which must have been usually administered by his travelling
companion;

text: 'Elton is being assessed as a performer.  Remember the language surrounding his riddle: that was just prologue to a longer play, according to Emma.  But this may be a play that only she is watching, or that only she thinks she knows the plot of.'
quote: 'This was very proper; the sigh which accompanied it was really\r\nestimable; but it should have lasted longer.

text: 'The male pissing match continues here.  Think of Austen to some degree as an anthropologist assessing who the alpha males are, what the uses of restrained aggressivity are in a seemingly unfailingly civilized society.'
quote: '"I cannot wish to be snowed up a week at Randalls."

text: 'Pairs and comparisons are important to any Austen novel, and such a line signals you to be on the lookout for larger contrasts between male characters as the novel develops.'
quote: 'Elton must compose his\r\njoyous looks, and Mr. John Knightley disperse his ill-humour.

text: 'Notice how the hints of the language of the theater here -- "prompted," "[show] herself" -- undercut to some degree the authenticity seemingly suggested.'
quote: 'might be as nature prompted, and shew herself just as\r\nhappy as she was.

text: 'Is a ''women''s world'' being carved out in such lines?  What pace of life and what sort of attention are being described as staples of the feminine domain here?'
quote: 'half an hour''s uninterrupted\r\ncommunication of all those little matters on which the daily happiness\r\nof private life depends, was one of the first gratifications of each.

text: 'You might cross-reference the motif of riddles here -- is there a desire in Emma that love and desire should make rational sense?  That they should not be riddling or nonsensical?'
quote: 'Mr.\r\nElton''s nonsense,

text: 'Emma is in love with an abstraction, a man she''s never met.  Note how closely this attraction to an abstraction follows upon a moment in which a suitor won''t conform to her idealized version of what his desires ought to be.'
quote:
'something in the name, in the idea of Mr. Frank
Churchill, which always interested her. She had frequently
thought--especially since his father''s marriage with Miss Taylor--that
if she were to marry, he was the very person to suit her in
age, character and condition.

text: 'Were she to marry Frank, Mr. Weston would of course become Emma''s father-in-law.  Is she seeking out a surrogate family, in a sense, by seeking out a husband?  Some of the language here is suggestive of that.'
quote:
'"We want only two more to be just the right number. I should like to
see two more here,--your pretty little friend, Miss Smith, and my
son--and then I should say we were quite complete. I believe you did
not hear me telling the others in the drawing-room that we are
expecting Frank. I had a letter from him this morning, and he will be
with us within a fortnight."

text: 'Pay attention to the "reading" given here of Frank''s intentions and his family situation.  Just as with riddles, Austen is intent on laying out many possibilities of interpretation for the mind curious about a person or potential suitor.'
quote: 'a certain lady, of some consequence, at Enscombe, has\r\na particular dislike to:

text: 'We''ve seen (absurd) laws of the father.  Is a law of the mother (or aunt) being asserted here?'
quote: 'Mrs. Churchill rules at Enscombe, and is a very odd-tempered\r\nwoman; and his coming now, depends upon her being willing to spare him."

text: 'Emma gives voice here to a set of facts about male vs. female confinement and mobility.  Note how much of Austen''s plot is generated by departures and arrivals of men, while women remain stationary and try to interpret their unseen actions.'
quote: 'A young woman , if\r\nshe fall into bad hands, may be teazed, and kept at a distance from\r\nthose she wants to be with; but one cannot comprehend a young man'' s being under such restraint, as not to be able to spend a week with his father, if he likes it."

text: 'It''s strange, isn''t it, how a love triangle of sorts has developed -- Emma, Frank Churchill, Mr. Elton -- with no actual actions on the part of any of those involved.  It''s an entirely imaginary love triangle -- and, more to the point, almost entirely in Emma''s head.'
quote:
'Emma, in good spirits too, from the amusement afforded her mind by
the expectation of Mr. Frank Churchill, was willing to forget his late
improprieties, and be as well satisfied with him as before, and on his
making Harriet his very first subject, was ready to listen with most
friendly smiles.

text: 'Notice how deftly Austen''s trademark indirect third-person narrative -- also known as free indirect discourse -- keeps us very close to Emma''s interpretation of what''s being said by Mr. Elton, while still maintaining a semblance of objective narration.  This is Austen''s great achievement, what she will always be remembered for in the history of the English novel.'
quote:
'But at last there seemed a perverse turn; it seemed all at once as
if he were more afraid of its being a bad sore throat on her account,
than on Harriet''s--more anxious that she should escape the infection,
than that there should be no infection in the complaint. He began with
great earnestness to entreat her to refrain from visiting the
sick-chamber again, for the present--to entreat her to promise him not to venture into such hazard till he had seen Mr. Perry and learnt
his opinion; and though she tried to laugh it off and bring the subject
back into its proper course, there was no putting an end to his extreme
solicitude about her. She was vexed.

text: 'Keep track of moments in which Emma''s language fails her and she is reduced to silence.'
quote: 'She could only give him a look; but it was such a look as\r\nshe thought must restore him to his senses, and then left the sofa,\r\nremoving to a seat by her sister, and giving her all her attention.

text: 'There is something perverse and taunting in this speech by John Knightley.'
quote:
'"I admired your resolution very much, sir," said he, "in venturing
out in such weather, for of course you saw there would be snow very
soon. Every body must have seen the snow coming on. I admired your
spirit; and I dare say we shall get home very well. Another hour or
two''s snow can hardly make the road impassable; and we are two
carriages; if one is blown over in the bleak part of the common field
there will be the other at hand. I dare say we shall be all safe at
Hartfield before midnight."

text: 'A woman''s ability to walk is again at issue, with certain metaphorical implications.'
quote:
'"You had better order the carriage directly, my love," said she; "I
dare say we shall be able to get along, if we set off directly; and if
we do come to any thing very bad, I can get out and walk. I am not at
all afraid. I should not mind walking half the way. I could change my
shoes, you know, the moment I got home; and it is not the sort of thing
that gives me cold." "Indeed!" replied he. "Then, my dear Isabella, it is the most
extraordinary sort of thing in the world, for in general every thing
does give you cold. Walk home!--you are prettily shod for walking home,
I dare say. It will be bad enough for the horses."

text: 'The motif of women accommodating men''s desires and temperaments again comes up.'
quote:
'And the bell was rung, and the carriages spoken for. A few minutes
more, and Emma hoped to see one troublesome companion deposited in his
own house, to get sober and cool, and the other recover his temper and
happiness when this visit of hardship were over.

text: 'The intention of all of Austen''s complicated plotting regarding this carriage ride is now revealed.'
quote: 'so that Emma found, on being escorted and followed into the\r\nsecond carriage by Mr. Elton, that the door was to be lawfully shut on\r\nthem, and that they were to have a tete-a-tete drive.

text: 'Austen''s sentences register this "violence" in the only way her sense of propriety allowed: by a "cut[ting] up" of "subject," a grammar of em dashes and headlong prose.  It is (from a modern perspective) one of Austen''s limitations that such moments are rarely felt as impositions on a woman''s body -- there is abstraction even in the most visceral moments.'
quote: 'making violent love to her:

text: 'But of course she''s been misinterpreting them all along.'
quote: 'attentions as I have been in the daily habit\r\nof observing--to

text: '"Sanguine" means confident, cheerful, but the joke seems to lie in the fact that his cheeks would be flushed with blood from wine, exhilaration, embarrassment ("sanguine" comes from "sang" or "blood").'
quote: 'Mr. Elton''s sanguine state of\r\nmind,

text: 'Again, keep track of Emma''s moments of silence.  Here, so long the perpetrator of interpretations, she becomes the object of interpretation herself.'
quote: 'this interesting silence.

text: 'The theme of women accommodating the feelings of men -- rather than engaging with them in relationships of equality -- here reaches a fever pitch at chapter''s end.'
quote: 'He was too angry to say another word;

text: 'Emma may be growing here, in finding a need for "quiet reflection."  Up till now, in contrast with many an Austen heroine, we''ve seen her as an almost entirely social being.  But she needs to figure things out for herself, alone.'
quote: 'the relief of quiet reflection.

text: 'Austen takes a pause to gather up several plot strands here, looking backward and forward.  You should focus more on the details of the acts of misinterpretation and what they say about character rather than simply saying that you saw it coming, that Austen''s techniques of suspense aren''t modern enough for you.'
quote:
'The hair was curled, and the maid sent away, and Emma sat down to
think and be miserable.--It was a wretched business indeed!--Such an
overthrow of every thing she had been wishing for!--Such a development
of every thing most unwelcome!--Such a blow for Harriet!--that was the
worst of all. Every part of it brought pain and humiliation, of some
sort or other; but, compared with the evil to Harriet, all was light;
and she would gladly have submitted to feel yet more mistaken-- more in
error--more disgraced by mis-judgment, than she actually was, could the
effects of her blunders have been confined to herself.

text: 'The idea that love relationships should make a certain sense again emerges.  Austen''s first novel, Sense and Sensibility, suggested in the balance of its title terms that one needs both rational sense and an ability to feel sensations deeply to achieve true love and happiness.  Emma may need some of that balance here.'
quote: 'nonsense?

text: 'There are few shades of nuance here: when a character gets someone wrong, she gets him dramatically wrong.  Sudden reversals in a person''s characterization are what an Austen plot often turns on.'
quote:
'Mr. Elton was proving himself, in many
respects, the very reverse of what she had meant and believed him;
proud, assuming, conceited; very full of his own claims, and little
concerned about the feelings of others.

text: 'We can track Emma''s maturation by separating out this new judgement of Elton and seeing how apt it proves.  In a relatively static plot, such changes of mind and judgement are incredibly important to seeing the contours of the novel.'
quote: 'Sighs and fine words had been given in abundance;\r\nbut she could hardly devise any set of expressions, or fancy any tone\r\nof voice, less allied with real love.

text: 'Class too asserts itself as part of this new judgement.  Will this prove to be the blind spot in Emma''s new judgement, or will Austen vindicate this desire to marry a class equal?'
quote:
'if Miss
Woodhouse of Hartfield, the heiress of thirty thousand pounds, were not
quite so easily obtained as he had fancied, he would soon try for Miss
Somebody else with twenty, or with ten.

text: 'Harsh?  Judge for yourself to what degree the discourse of social status determines Emma''s perceptions of this suitor.'
quote: 'the\r\nEltons were nobody.

text: 'More learning for Emma: here she is able to see outside the confines of her perspective, and she progresses not so much as one who corrects her own actions as one who is able to see broader points about the nature of interpreting others -- the nature of "reading."'
quote: 'she had so misinterpreted his feelings, she had little right to wonder that he , with self-interest to blind him, should have mistaken hers.

text: 'Recall the language about the "subject" being "cut up" in the carriage ride with Elton.  The value underlying such language seems to be a belief in natural harmony and integration -- of the person, of the social order in which he or she exists.  In the latter case, social hierarchy seems to play an important part in maintaining that sense of harmony.  For such reasons readers have often found Austen to be innately conservative on questions of social order.'
quote: 'her peace is cut up for some time.\r\nI

text: 'The word means showy display, and it ties into the ongoing theme of the theatrical, the performative -- and its avoidance.'
quote: 'eclat,

text: 'This seems a grim state, but here, as we move toward the middle third of the novel, it is also suggestive a springtime -- literal and metaphorical -- to come.  Emma''s learning about love coincides with a winter-time state of inwardness and remaining indoors -- states that a person in the early nineteenth century would have felt more acutely than we do today, of course, in our climate-controlled environments.'
quote:
'The ground covered
with snow, and the atmosphere in that unsettled state between frost and
thaw, which is of all others the most unfriendly for exercise, every
morning beginning in rain or snow, and every evening setting in to
freeze, she was for many days a most honourable prisoner.

text: 'Austen looks ahead to her next plot point.'
quote: 'still\r\nsuch an evil hanging over her in the hour of explanation with Harriet,\r\nas made it impossible for Emma to be ever perfectly at ease.

text: 'Who''s right about Isabella''s state?  You should sit up attentively, of course, when Austen starts to speak of models "of right feminine happiness," for that is what, in a sense, the whole novel is about.  Recognize that Mr. Woodhouse''s interpretation of his daughter may be a plot of misreading running in parallel to those featuring Emma.'
quote:
'his lamentations over the destiny of poor
Isabella;--which poor Isabella, passing her life with those she doated
on, full of their merits, blind to their faults, and always innocently
busy, might have been a model of right feminine happiness.

text: 'Men are mobile, women are not -- a fact reinforced by the juxtaposition of this notice with Emma''s thoughts, in the previous chapter, about feeling like a "prisoner."'
quote:
'he was proposing to leave
Highbury the following morning in his way to Bath; where, in compliance
with the pressing entreaties of some friends, he had engaged to spend a
few weeks,

text: 'Why do you think Emma takes this so hard?  Is there an effort here on Austen''s part to make her learning more dramatic by putting it in terms of religious transformation and redemption (penance, confession)?  This could in fact be the consequence of having set out to write a novel with a central character who starts out at such an extreme -- who starts out lacking knowledge more thoroughly than any other Austen heroine.'
quote:
'She went
to Mrs. Goddard''s accordingly the very next day, to undergo the
necessary penance of communication; and a severe one it was.-- She had
to destroy all the hopes which she had been so industriously
feeding--to appear in the ungracious character of the one preferred--
and acknowledge herself grossly mistaken and mis-judging in all her
ideas on one subject, all her observations, all her convictions, all
her prophecies for the last six weeks.

text: 'In a chapter of extremes, this may represent another.  For does it seem likely that Austen would want a heroine who "repress[es]" her "imagination" entirely?  That would be too great a penance.  The idea that female characters embodied a fund of imagination was important to the work of Henry James, who, in Portrait of a Lady, presents a woman, Isabel Archer, who is full of imagination and also misinterprets the love situation in which she finds herself.  In James, though, the consequences of misreading others are harsher, darker.'
quote: 'repressing imagination all the rest\r\nof her life.

text: 'Emma''s "sense" asserts itself here, over and against the sensibility represented by Harriet, who is no master of her emotions.'
quote:
'Harriet did think him all perfection, and maintained the
non-existence of any body equal to him in person or goodness--and did,
in truth, prove herself more resolutely in love than Emma had foreseen;
but yet it appeared to her so natural, so inevitable to strive against
an inclination of that sort unrequited , that she could not comprehend its continuing very long in equal force.

text: 'Again, in a chapter of extremes, a compromise position, a realistic one, is ultimately reached.'
quote: 'They must encounter each\r\nother, and make the best of it.

text: 'The motif of sickness here gets tied up with the love theme -- and a motif of love-sickness begins to emerge.  But it''s true as well that Harriet is "thinking" too much with her body and emotions here -- never the truest path in Austen.'
quote: 'Where the wound had been given, there must the cure\r\nbe found if anywhere; and Emma felt that, till she saw her in the way\r\nof cure, there could be no true peace for herself.

text: 'As we reach the end of the first volume, Austen keeps her suspense structure intact for future volumes.'
quote: 'Mr. Frank Churchill did not come.

text: 'What sort of emotional economy is implied here?  Is the idea that one must "pay" for every happiness one eventually gets?  How would you relate such ideas to Emma''s trajectory?'
quote: 'pay for its hopes

text: 'Emma''s performative nature is again brought up.  Note that it here is brought into implicit conflict with Mr. Knightley and his forthright manner.'
quote: 'acting a part,

text: 'The contrast between Knightley (Englishness) and Churchill (French ways) is propounded. '
quote:
'"I am not supposing him at all an unnatural creature, in suspecting
that he may have learnt to be above his connexions, and to care very
little for any thing but his own pleasure, from living with those who
have always set him the example of it.

text: 'While Emma might be wrong about Frank Churchill in this particular case, her speech about "dependency" is really about her own status as a woman.  Often debates in Austen take place on many hidden levels like this.'
quote:
'"That''s easily said, and easily felt by you, who have always been
your own master. You are the worst judge in the world, Mr. Knightley,
of the difficulties of dependence. You do not know what it is to have
tempers to manage."

text: 'What is really at issue in the debate over Frank is a man''s mobility, and how, given that freedom, he makes moral choices in using it.'
quote: 'This proves that he can\r\nleave the Churchills."

text:
'

The theme of men and morality and "duty" is driven home in a forceful speech by Knightley.

'
quote: '"There is one thing, Emma, which a man can always do, if he chuses,\r\nand that is, his duty; not by manoeuvring and finessing, but by vigour\r\nand resolution.

text: 'Austen would have been much aware of contemporary books of moral conduct that gave instructions on being a proper gentleman or proper gentlewoman.  In many ways her novels are written in response to such discourses, giving a far more nuanced picture of the realities of morality and their frequent lack of connection to one''s class status.'
quote: 'could!--How can you imagine such conduct\r\npracticable?"

text: 'Emma is, in a sense, going to school in such moments.  Note how sophisticated her reading of a man''s intentions and limitations have become, now that she has overcome her early, simplistic misreading of Mr. Elton.  She is beginning to see others as much fuller pictures.'
quote:
'"I rather doubt that. You are very fond of bending little minds; but
where little minds belong to rich people in authority, I think they
have a knack of swelling out, till they are quite as unmanageable as
great ones. I can imagine, that if you, as you are, Mr. Knightley, were
to be transported and placed all at once in Mr. Frank Churchill''s
situation, you would be able to say and do just what you have been
recommending for him; and it might have a very good effect. The
Churchills might not have a word to say in return; but then, you would
have no habits of early obedience and long observance to break through.
To him who has, it might not be so easy to burst forth at once into
perfect independence, and set all their claims on his gratitude and
regard at nought. He may have as strong a sense of what would be right,
as you can have, without being so equal, under particular
circumstances, to act up to it."

text: 'The line recalls Emma''s earlier associations with children.'
quote: 'I can\r\nallow for the fears of the child, but not of the man.

text: 'Here you should have in mind as a counter-image all the tantalizingness afforded by riddles in the earlier parts of the novel.  Knightley throws down a gauntlet on the type of living that exults in and indulges word-play, not saying what you mean, etc.  As you head into the novel''s middle third, you should see how such a resolve fares.'
quote:
'He can sit down and write a fine
flourishing letter, full of professions and falsehoods, and persuade
himself that he has hit upon the very best method in the world of
preserving peace at home and preventing his father''s having any right
to complain. His letters disgust me."

text: 'The French/English dichotomy here is explicitly treated.  Antipathy between the English and French should be understood in the context of the Napoleonic Wars, which took place between 1803 and 1815 (i.e., during the years in which Emma was composed).  Austen had a brother in the Royal Navy and was particularly aware of the events of these wars.'
quote:
'No, Emma, your amiable young man can be amiable only in
French, not in English. He may be very `aimable,'' have very good
manners, and be very agreeable; but he can have no English delicacy
towards the feelings of other people: nothing really amiable about him."
